Uncertainty

In-class example

Here‚Äôs the code we‚Äôll be using in class. Download it and store it with the rest of your materials for this course. If simply clicking doesn‚Äôt trigger download, you should right-click and select ‚Äúsave link as‚Ä¶‚Äù

  • Day one: üë©‚Äçüíª 09-uncertainty.R

Example using stevedata

Let‚Äôs look at data on abortion attitudes from the stevedata package. We‚Äôll use the gss_abortion dataset.

library(tidyverse)
library(moderndive)
library(stevedata)

gss_abortion
# A tibble: 64,814 √ó 18
      id  year   age race  sex    hispaniccat  educ partyid       relactiv abany
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <chr>        <dbl> <dbl> <chr>            <dbl> <dbl>
 1     1  1972    23 White Female          NA    16 Ind,Near Dem        NA    NA
 2     2  1972    70 White Male            NA    10 Not Str Demo‚Ä¶       NA    NA
 3     3  1972    48 White Female          NA    12 Independent         NA    NA
 4     4  1972    27 White Female          NA    17 Not Str Demo‚Ä¶       NA    NA
 5     5  1972    61 White Female          NA    12 Strong Democ‚Ä¶       NA    NA
 6     6  1972    26 White Male            NA    14 Ind,Near Dem        NA    NA
 7     7  1972    28 White Male            NA    13 Ind,Near Dem        NA    NA
 8     8  1972    27 White Male            NA    16 Ind,Near Dem        NA    NA
 9     9  1972    21 Black Female          NA    12 Strong Democ‚Ä¶       NA    NA
10    10  1972    30 Black Female          NA    12 Strong Democ‚Ä¶       NA    NA
# ‚Ñπ 64,804 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 8 more variables: abdefect <dbl>, abnomore <dbl>, abhlth <dbl>,
#   abpoor <dbl>, abrape <dbl>, absingle <dbl>, pid <dbl>, hispanic <dbl>

We‚Äôd like to know how the average American feels about abortion, but this is unknowable: we can‚Äôt survey everyone, there‚Äôs measurement error, etc.

Let‚Äôs pretend for a minute that we can know do this: we survey all Americans, perfectly, and they are all captured in gss_abortion. Only 64,000 Americans exist in this imaginary world.

What percent of Americans support abortion? We take the average of abany (a binary variable that equals 1 if the respondent thinks abortion should be legal for any reason):

gss_abortion |> 
  summarise(avg_abortion = mean(abany, na.rm = TRUE))
# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_abortion
         <dbl>
1        0.414

So 41% of Americans in this imaginary world think abortion should be legal for any reason.

But what if instead of having access to the full population of Americans (gss_abortion), we only had a sample of 10 people? Let‚Äôs take 1,000 samples from gss_abortion, each of size 10, and calculate the average support for abortion in each of those samples:

set.seed(1990)

samples = rep_sample_n(gss_abortion, size = 10, reps = 1000) |> 
  summarise(avg_abortion = mean(abany, na.rm = TRUE))
samples
# A tibble: 1,000 √ó 2
   replicate avg_abortion
       <int>        <dbl>
 1         1        0.143
 2         2        1    
 3         3        0.2  
 4         4        0.333
 5         5        0.25 
 6         6        0    
 7         7        0.429
 8         8        0.4  
 9         9        0.167
10        10        0.333
# ‚Ñπ 990 more rows

We can plot this:

ggplot(samples, aes(x = avg_abortion)) +
  geom_density() + 
  labs(title = "Distribution of abortion attitudes in 1,000 samples of 10 Americans",
       x = "Proportion of Americans who support abortion",
       y = "Frequency")

We can see a lot of variation. Remember, the true population average is 41%.

We can ask other questions of these sample estimates. For example, across the 1,000 samples, what is the average sample estimate of the proportion of Americans who support abortion?

samples |> 
  summarise(avg_avg_abortion = mean(avg_abortion))
# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  avg_avg_abortion
             <dbl>
1            0.422

It‚Äôs 42%, which is pretty close to the population average.

What is the range of sample estimates of the proportion of Americans who support abortion? This is the difference between the largest and smallest sample average:

samples |> 
  summarise(range_avg_abortion = max(avg_abortion) - min(avg_abortion))
# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
  range_avg_abortion
               <dbl>
1                  1

In this case it‚Äôs 100%, because in the smallest sample average we observed 0% support for abortion and the largest sample average we observed 100% support for abortion.
